name: pathologically
content:
pathologically adverb
(BEHAVIOUR)
Add to word list
Add to word list
in a way that is not reasonable or normal, or cannot be controlled: He comes across as pathologically ambitious. They become pathologically obsessed with their body image.
More examplesFewer examplesAs a mother, she was overprotective and pathologically controlling.She wanted to get away from her pathologically jealous husband.Much of the film is viewed through the perceptions of Jorge, a pathologically shy, nearly mute dishwasher. To avoid research projects involving rats or hamsters, of which she is pathologically terrified, she did a project on human bones and left with a PhD in bone identification.The National Council on Problem Gambling estimates that about 1 percent of US adults pathologically gamble.

pathologically adverb
(DISEASE)
in a way that relates to disease, especially its causes and effects or its diagnosis by the scientific examination of body tissue: The cancer was proven to be stage B, pathologically. These lesions can be very difficult to differentiate both radiologically and pathologically.
More examplesFewer examplespathologically normal tissueDiagnosis is difficult both clinically and pathologically. Pathologically, the most common primary brain tumour in adults is a glioma.
